key_title: Key to the genera of Asteraceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Asteraceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Asteraceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Capitula unisexual, male and females very dissimilar; male capitula in terminal clusters or racemes; female capitula in lower axils, enveloped in fused bracts forming hard spiny burrs at maturity (corolla and pappus absent)
Capitula bisexual, or if unisexual then sexes not very dissimilar; capitula not forming burrs in fruit, if sometimes with stiff barbed bristles, then borne in terminal heads
Capitula with all florets tubular or some florets ligulate, mostly 3- or 4-lobed; lacking milky sap
Capitula with all florets ligulate, 5-lobed (commonly yellow); leaves, stems etc., exuding milky sap when broken

All florets tubular and/or some filiform, or if some ligulate, then ligules less than 3 mm long (but involucral bracts sometimes coloured and resembling ligules, or, rarely lobes of corolla long and resembling ligules)
Outer florets with ligules longer than 3 mm
Involucral bracts not spine-tipped; receptacle usually glabrous; styles usually glabrous

Involucral bracts (and often leaves) spine-tipped or comb-like at apex; receptacle usually with scales, bristles or hairs; styles usually with hairs below stigma branches (thistles and similar plants)
Inflorescence a compound head, with capitula clustered on a common receptacle, the whole usually surrounded by an involucre of scales or leaves
Inflorescence of simple capitula, solitary, or if variously grouped (in cymes, panicles etc.) then not surrounded by a common involucre
Leaves opposite at least at base, rarely in whorls
Leaves all alternate and/or radical
Leaves lobed to deeply divided
Leaves entire or toothed
Involucral bracts fused into tube; plant strongly odorous
Involucral bracts free; plants usually odourless
[link through]
Pappus of 2–4 stiff, barbed awns; receptacle scales present (but not persistent)
Pappus of 8–10 membranous scales (sometimes darkly striated at the apex); receptacle scales absent
[link through]
Involucral bracts 5, fused for more than half their length; capitula solitary, on short decurved peduncles from upper axils; extensively rhizomatous subshrubs
Plants not combining the above characteristics
[link through]
Cypselas narrow-cylindric with a long straight or curved beak; outer florets strongly decurved in upper part, overhanging involucre
Cypselas and florets lacking the above combination of characters
Pappus present, at least half as long as cypsela body
Pappus absent or very small
Pappus of 5–40 scabrid bristles not expanded at base; cypselas 1–2.5 mm long
Pappus of 2–4 retrorsely barbed awns or 3–8 bristles expanded at base; cypselas 2.8–12 mm long
Pappus shorter than cypsela body, of 2–4 stiff, barbed awns; leaves usually lobed or compound, 6 cm long or more
Pappus longer than cypsela body, of 3–8 c. lanceolate scales, tapering to bristle- like tips; leaves simple, more or less conduplicate, under 2 cm long
[link through]
All florets bisexual, similar in appearance
Outer florets female with only style present, filiform or ligulate, sometimes ligule very short, inner florets bisexual or functionaly male
Cypselas flat with involute herbaceous wings with large incurved appendages at the apex; small annuals of north-west
Cypselas obovoid to obloid, lacking wings or appendages; annuals or perennials
[link through]
Capitula sessile, axillary; involucral bracts scarious, all erect or incurved, non-glandular; receptacle without scales; leaves under 1 cm long; rare north-western herb to c. 10 cm high

Capitula pedunculate, in terminal cymes; involucral bracts herbaceous, the outer ones spreading, inner ones erect, usually glandular; receptacle with scales; leaves mostly longer than 2 cm; erect to spreading herbs mostly more than 30 cm high
[link through]
Involucral bracts in 1 series (sometimes a few much shorter bracts present at base of involucre), usually fused (at least at base); capitula simple
Involucral bracts in 2 or more whorls and free, or inflorescence a compound head
Inflorescence of simple capitula, or if ever apparently a compound head, then capitula heterogamous (with inner floret or florets bisexual and the outer female)
Inflorescence a compound head, individual capitula homogamous, clustered on a common receptacle, the whole with or without a common involucre of scales or leaves
Pappus of bristles or scales at least subequal to the cypsela
Pappus absent or reduced to a vestigial scarious cup
Capitula 4–6-flowered, crowded into small clusters; at least the inner 2 capitular bracts with slightly hardened, hooked apices; leaves spathulate, grey-cottony
If capitula ever clustered then inner capitular bracts never with hooked apices
Leaves deeply lobed to pinnate (sometimes with several orders of division)
Leaves entire, toothed or shallowly lobed
Cypselas distinctly (but sometimes very shortly) beaked
Cypselas without distinct beak
Cypselas with a short beak (much less than half the length of the entire cypsela), glandular near apex; capitula on long, erect peduncles; leaves mostly rosetted or contracted near base
Cypselas with a long beak (more than half the length of the entire cypsela), woolly near apex; c. prostrate herbs; leaves mostly cauline
Subshrubby biennials or short-lived perennials to c. 3 m high, highly aromatic, with large, stem-clasping leaves (at least near base); inflorescence a large, drooping terminal panicle
Habit not as above
[link through]
Receptacle with scales; capitula surrounded by numerous white, papery involucral bracts; stems usually winged to some extent
Receptacle naked; habit otherwise not as above
Herb; stems strongly winged; far east only
Shrub; stems slightly winged from decurrent leaf-bases; western
[link through]
[link through]
All florets tubular to campanulate
Outer florets reduced, filiform or with a small ligule; differing in shape from the inner florets
Involucral bracts multiseriate; shrubs
Involucral bracts in 2 series; herbs
Annual herbs with wiry stems; corolla woolly at base, glandular near apex
Annual or perennial herbs lacking wiry stems; corolla glabrous, non-glandular
Cypselas non-pedicellate, the outer ones glabrous, not winged; inner cypselas not developing; very rare creeping herb of high-alpine areas
Cypselas pedicellate, dimorphic, the outer ones glandular-hairy, winged; the inner ones sparsely glandular-hairy, with narrow marginal ridge
[link through]
Pappus of bristle-like hairs present when flowering, caducous from mature cypselas; involucral bracts clawed, the inner ones with papery white or coloured lamina
Pappus absent or minute throughout floral development; involucral bracts not clawed, all green and herbaceous or sometimes with a membranous or pigmented margin
Leaves all rosetted at base
Leaves along erect or creeping stems and at base
Capitula solitary on terminal peduncles
Capitula in terminal panicles or racemes, or axillary and nearly sessile
Outer florets with small, deeply 3-lobed yellow ligules
Outer florets tubular to filiform
[link through]
Cypselas with 8–10 fine ribs, continuing to apex of cypsela; plants more or less inodorous; involucral bracts 3–4-seriate
Cypselas with 3–5 obtuse ribs, often terminating below apex of cypsela; plants aromatic; involucral bracts c. 2-seriate
Capitula globose to ovoid in terminal panicles; leaves sessile; erect perennials
Capitula broadly hemispherical, solitary in leaf axils; leaves with a petiole-like base; prostrate to ascending annual to perennial
[link through]
[link through]
Cypselas broadly winged, sharply contracted above into 1 or more apical spines; prostrate herb with capitula sessile amongst the leaves
Cypselas and habit not as above
[link through]
Capitula numerous in dense compound corymbs or panicles; rhizomatous peren- nials with c. erect stems
Capitula solitary or in few-flowered corymbs (rarely dense-flowered in annual Matricaria suffruticosa); annuals or decumbent perennials
Outer florets with ligules to c. 3 mm long
Outer florets without ligules
Capitula dull yellow or reddish, in leafy panicles
Capitula bright yellow, in dense corymbs
Florets sessile on the receptacle which appears slightly pitted when cypselas have fallen
Florets minutely pedicellate, the pedicel persisting on the receptacle when ripe cypselas have fallen
Receptacle c. conical, hollow; leaves green, glabrescent
Receptacle flat or convex, solid; leaves grey-green, pubescent
Disc florets usually fertile, style bifid; cypselas with blunt-tipped hairs on surface; plants c. erect or decumbent, sometimes rooting at nodes
Disc florets sterile, style ending in a circular disc; cypselas glabrous; plants c. prostrate, creeping, rooting at nodes
Plants dioecious, with capitula functionally unisexual; uncommon plants of mallee, central goldfields or higher alps
Plants not dioecius; capitula with all florets bisexual or marginal florets female and inner florets bisexual or functionally male
Prostrate herbs of higher alps
Erect or ascending herbs or shrubs to 2 m high of mallee or central goldfields
Leaves c. obovate, densely silvery- or brownish-sericeous; involucral bracts with short white papery lamina; cypselas appressed-hairy, with deciduous pappus
Leaves linear, mucronate, glabrous; involucral bracts lacking white papery lamina; cypselas glabrous, with persistent pappus
[link through]
[link through]
Leaves black gland-dotted, resinous, glabrous
Leaves not gland-dotted or resinous, surfaces white-grey-tomentose
[link through]
Pappus of 2 straight, diverging, retrorsely barbed awns 1–3 (–5) mm long; rare, few-leaved perennial herb of far east
Pappus not as above
[link through]
Pappus cup-like or crown-like of free or united scales (sometimes fringed along margin)
Pappus of smooth, barbed or plumose bristles (sometimes broadened and scale- like at base)
Florets each subtended by a scarious scale which persists on the receptacle; stems prominently winged; white-woolly herb of far east
Florets not each subtended by a scale; stems not winged
[link through]
Cypselas densely hairy or with long white antrorse  hairs
Cypselas glabrous or with scattered globose hairs or glands
Involucral bracts 6–11 (–14) mm long; capitula 2.5–4 cm diam.
Involucral bracts 2.5–5 mm long; capitula less than 1 cm diam.
Decumbent to ascending herb; capitula terminal, pedunculate, exceeding leaves
Tufted, grass-like herb; capitula basal, sessile amongst leaves and greatly exceeded by them
[link through]
Leaves deeply dissected; ray floret ligulate, solitary; pappus scales dark-striated
Leaves entire; ray florets absent; pappus scales not darkly striated
[link through]
Perennial; leaves longer than 1 cm; capitula pedunculate
Annual; leaves linear, c. fleshy, under 1 cm long; capitula sessile
[link through]
Shrubs, with persistent, woody stems
Annual or perennial herbs, rarely subshrubs then woody only near base
Involucral bracts herbaceous, usually green (sometimes tinged purple or obscured by hairs); inflorescence usually with few capitula or capitula solitary
Involucral bracts scarious, glabrous, white, yellow or reddish; inflorescence usu- ally a corymb of many capitula
Capitula with all florets similar; capitula button-like, bright yellow, each with at least 100 florets; garden-escape in near-coastal areas

Capitula with outer fertile female florets surrounding bisexual florets; total number of florets usually far fewer than 100 per capitulum (except in O. frostii, endemic on the Bogong High Plains); native species
[link through]
Receptacle bracts present (resembling involucral bracts but narrower and usually thinner-textured); involucral bracts all c. erect, straight or apices incurved, not or hardly apically dilated
Receptacle bracts (subtending individual florets) absent, or if ever present, then inner involucral bracts with spreading, usually dilated apical part
Semi-woody shrub with broadly elliptic leaves 5-10 mm long, 3-6 mm wide, densely white tomentose beneath, grey-green above; rays of involucral bracts white, spreading.
Woody, native shrubs; combined characters not as above
Outer florets with small ligules
Outer florets not differentiated from inner florets, or at least without ligules
Outer involucral bracts sessile; inner bracts with scarious lamina on longer, herbaceous to hardened claws
Outer involucral bracts not differing markedly from the inner ones; inner bracts lacking claws
Ligules and disc florets all yellow
Ligules white to blue, purple or pink; disc florets usually a contrasting colour, typically yellow or violet
Dwarf shrub with terete, somewhat fleshy leaves; gypseous areas of the north-west
Herbs with flat non-succulent leaves
[link through]
Annual, sticky and aromatic due to glandular hairs; anthers tailed at the base
Perennial with rhizomes, non-glandular; anthers obtuse at the base
[link through]
Disc florets sterile, producing abortive cypselas with pappus differing from those of ray florets
Disc florets fertile; pappus of both ray and disc florets similar
Capitula numerous in panicles or corymbs; erect herbs with numerous cauline leaves (a basal rosette sometimes present)
Capitula solitary or in loose groups of 2–4; leaves mainly basal, usually rosetted; alpine or subalpine herbs
Plants with conspicuous hairs on stems and leaves
Plants glabrous or nearly so (sometimes glandular-pubescent immediately below inflorescence)
Peduncles and involucral bracts glabrous; widespread weed
Peduncles and involucral bracts glandular-pubescent; rare native of alpine areas, usually in rocky sites
Cypselas 2–2.5 mm long, sparsely pubescent; capitula in loose groups of  2–4
Cypselas 2.5–8 mm long, glabrous or very sparsely glandular; capitula solitary
Involucral bracts with fringed or comb-like apices, or with a lacerated apical appendage
Involucral bracts entire (commonly), or ciliate to lacerated along all or most of the margin (i.e. divisions not confined to apex)
Involucral bracts (at least outer ones) with ciliate or plumose margins
Involucral bracts lacking ciliate margins (but outer ones sometimes woolly or lacerate)
Lamina of involucral bracts conspicuous, lanceolate, papery, yellow to reddish; cypselas with a distinct filiform, sterile neck
Lamina of involucral bracts inconspicuous, c. linear, scarious to papery, if con- spicuously white or coloured then cypselas lacking a neck
[link through]
Capitula terminal on short branches, sessile, usually surrounded by a cluster of leaves
Capitula terminal on long peduncles; not surrounded by a cluster of leaves
[link through]
Lamina of involucral bracts filiform, densely plumose
Lamina of involucral bracts flat, ciliate
Corollas not extending beyond the level of the involucre; cypselas unribbed, with- out a distinct neck
Corollas extending beyond the level of the involucre; cypselas 3- or 4-ribbed, often with a distinct sterile neck
Pappus bristles 16–24; cypselas smooth; outer involucral bracts linear
Pappus bristles less than 16 or if greater than 16 then cypsela scabrous and/or involucral bracts elliptic, ovate or lanceolate
Involucral bracts uniseriate or almost so, equal, herbaceous
Involucral bracts multiseriate, frequently with inner bracts longer than the outer ones, herbaceous to scarious or coloured
Involucral bracts completely herbaceous or with membranous or scarious margins and apex, herbaceous region sometimes reduced and apex expanded; petaloid, papery white or coloured lamina absent
Involucral bracts with lamina (or at least apex of bract) papery and opaque, white or coloured; with or without a cartilaginous base or claw

Stems narrowly winged from decurrent leaf bases (wings c.0.2–2 mm wide); leaf margins dentate, denticulate or crenate (or sometimes entire in Pterocaulon); florets pink; pappus 1-seriate; rare species of floodplain area of far north west
Stems without wings, leaf bases not decurrent; leaf margins various, usually entire; floret colour various, usually yellow, if ever pink or purple then either leaves entire or pappus 2-seriate
Capitula solitary or if congested, not in spherical, spike-like or raceme-like secondary heads; involucral bracts 3–4-seriate, inner bracts longer than outer ones; disc florets (1–)4–30(–50)
Capitula in congested spherical or spike-like or raceme-like secondary heads; involucral bracts 2-seriate, all similar in size; disc floret solitary (rarely 2)
Outer filiform florets in 2-several whorls
Filiform florets fewer than tubular bisexual florets or absent
Capitula pedunculate, usually in large panicles, not subtended by a whorl of leaves; involucral bracts herbaceous, sometimes with scarious margins; plants not woolly (but often hispid or strigose)

Capitula sessile to subsessile, usually in dense globose to spicate clusters (often subtended by a leaf or whorl of leaves), or solitary, or few in pedunculate, corymbose inflorescence; involucral bracts scarious; plants woolly to appressed-cottony, especially lower leaf surface
Capitula c. obconical, in small clusters surrounded and overtopped by leaves, and/or branches; innermost involucral bracts pouched and enveloping the outermost florets
Capitula and inner involucral bracts not as above
[link through]
Involucral bracts tapered into fine, awn-like apices c. 1 mm long; stems usually dichotomously (sometimes trichotomously) branched with a sessile cluster of capitula within each fork
Involucral bracts not awn-tipped; stems not typically dichotomously branched
[link through]
Capitula at least as wide as long, creamy; inner involucral bracts with a broad, cartilaginous claw especially visible after florets are shed
Capitula campanulate to urceolate, distinctly longer than wide, white or green- or pink-tinged; inner involucral bracts with a herbaceous central region but no dis- tinctive claw
[link through]
Capitula in spike-like or paniculate inflorescence; clusters of capitula usually sub- tended by a single leaf; cypselas with globose hairs
Capitula in c. hemispherical clusters subtended by a whorl of leaves, or solitary, or few in pedunculate, corymbose inflorescence
Plants not stoloniferous or with prostrate stems; involucres less than 3 mm long
Plants stoloniferous or with prostrate stems producing roots; involucres longer than 3 mm

Prostrate plants with stems upturning at tips and retaining living leaves while older stem retains older leaf bases and produces adventitious roots; cypselas at least 1 mm long; involucral bracts entire
Rooted leaf rosettes linked by stolons with long internodes and no roots; cypselas to 1 mm long or if longer then involucral bracts deeply lacerated at apex
Creeping, aromatic herb with glandular hairs; cypselas on short pedicels which persist on the receptacle; florets all tubular; pappus bristles 5
Habit not creeping, lacking the above combination of characters
[link through]
Receptacle with scales; plant a white-tomentose, aromatic herb 1–2 m high, with large, stem-clasping leaves; mostly near-coastal, but also Grampians
Receptacle lacking scales; plant lacking the above combination of characters
[link through]
Involucral bracts resinous, recurved to hooked at apex; leaves gland-dotted and resinous
Involucral bracts not with the above combination of features; leaves not gland-dotted or resinous
Pappus 2-seriate; outer bristles shorter than the inner; not fused; rare herb or subshrub of far east
Pappus l-seriate; shortly fused at the base and/or plumose from the base
[link through]
Pappus bristles plumose from the base
Pappus bristles barbellate or plumose only near tip
Cypselas glabrous or with globose, mucilage-producing cells
Cypselas hairy, lacking mucilage-producing cells
Involucral bracts linear or oblong, green and herbaceous throughout except for a small membranous apex
Involucral bracts with a conspicuous, broad and membranous or scarious apex, base cartilaginous and clawed or herbaceous and reduced and broadly triangular
Pappus plumose from the base (expanded basal region sometimes not or hardly ciliate)
Pappus barbellate or plumose only at the tip
Cypselas hairy, lacking mucilage-producing cells
Cypselas glabrous or with globose, mucilage-producing cells
Cypselas oblong to obovoid, smooth or papillose; pappus united in a ring at the base and falling as a unit; leaves semi-terete
Cypselas ellipsoid, warty; pappus persistent, eventually breaking shortly above base; leaves more or less flat
Corollas reddish, at least toward apex
Florets yellow
[link through]
Involucral bracts consisting of mainly a relatively broad, tough, stiffly scarious lamina, the cartilaginous base broad and greatly reduced
Involucral bracts with lamina papery or thinly scarious, and at least some of the bracts (usually intermediate) with elongated claws
Cypselas strongly constricted toward apex, often beaked; lamina of involucral bracts often ciliate on margins
Cypselas not strongly constricted toward apex, not beaked; lamina of involucral bracts not ciliate (but claws sometimes cottony)
Cypselas with scattered papillae and a distinct thickened pale basal collar (carpopodium)
Cypselas glabrous, or if ever with a few sparse papillae, lacking an indistinct basal collar (carpopodium)
Pappus bristles 80–100; involucral bracts white with broad herbaceous non-glandular claws
Pappus bristles 0–30; involucral bracts yellow or if white then with glandular claws
Common involucre surrounding the compound head of numerous scarious, opaque white or yellow bracts
Common involucre of few green leaves, scales or absent
Pappus of a single bristle; leaves narrow-linear, grass-like, glabrous or cobwebbed; compound heads sessile; plants under 10 cm high
Pappus of 9–15 bristles; leaves linear to lanceolate, glandular-pubescent; compound heads pedunculate; plants 10–50 cm high
[link through]
[link through]
Inflorescence sessile at ground-level, usually in a rosette of leaves; plants apparently stemless or stems prostrate
Inflorescence terminal on aerial or prostrate stems (sometimes stems branched just below inflorescence); if leaves ever rosetted then inflorescence stalked
Pappus present, of 4 or 5 stiff bristles fused at the base; stems absent or present; leaves spathulate to obovate; compound heads c. globular
Pappus absent; stemless annual with a rosette of linear-oblong leaves; compound head broad and flattish
[link through]
[link through]
Pappus present (but very short, crown-like in Trichanthodium) on at least the inner florets
Pappus absent
Corolla lacking hairs; common involucre present; individual capitula 1–3-flowered
Corolla hairy; common involucre absent; individual capitula many-flowered
Involucral bracts papillate at tips; leaves hairy at the base only
Involucral bracts not papillate at tips; leaves usually densely hairy
[link through]
Stems and leaves with cottony hairs
Stems and leaves with scale-like or bladder-like glandular hairs
Pappus of 8–12 subplumose bristles, united at the base for about half the length of corolla-tube; plants prostrate, with reddish, wiry stems terminating in very woolly compound heads
Pappus not as above; plants lacking the above combination of features
[link through]
Stems and leaves with scale-like or bladder-like glandular hairs
Stems and leaves with cottony hairs or glabrous
Pappus inconspicuous, if ever almost as long as corolla, then only of 3–6 slender bristles; inflorescences elongate or c. globose; small annuals of mallee areas in north-west
Pappus conspicuous, usually at least as long as corolla, and of 6 or more bristles; inflorescences c. globose to hemispherical; annuals or perennials
Compound heads elongate, ellipsoid to ovoid (often narrowly), general involucre absent or inconspicuous, less than half as long as compound heads
Compound heads c. globose, with a general involucre of leaf-like bracts at least half as long as compound heads
Involucral bracts tapered into fine, awn-like apices c. 1 mm long; stems usually dichotomously (sometimes trichotomously) branched with a sessile cluster of capitula within each fork
Involucral bracts not awn-tipped; habit not as above
[link through]
Compound heads overtopped by subtending leaves or leaf-like involucral bracts
Compound heads not exceeded by subtending leaves or bracts
[link through]
Cypselas glabrous to papillose
Cypselas hairy
Few-branched (or mostly basally branched) herbaceous perennials or annuals; not truly coastal
Much-branched, intricate, shrubby perennial of coastal dunes and cliffs
[link through]
Capitula pedunculate within the compound head; bracts and pappus hairs white (or bracts brown-tinged)
Capitula sessile within the compound head; bracts and pappus hairs yellow
Leaves opposite at least at base, rarely in whorls
Leaves all alternate and/or radical
Leaves lobed to deeply divided
Leaves entire or toothed
Involucral bracts fused into tube; plant strongly odorous
Involucral bracts free; plants usually odourless
[link through]
Pappus of 2–4 stiff, barbed awns; receptacle scales present (but not persistent)
Pappus of 8–10 membranous scales (sometimes darkly striated at the apex); receptacle scales absent
[link through]
Involucral bracts 5, fused for more than half their length; capitula solitary, on short decurved peduncles from upper axils; extensively rhizomatous subshrubs
Plants not combining the above characteristics
[link through]
Cypselas narrow-cylindric with a long straight or curved beak; outer florets strongly decurved in upper part, overhanging involucre
Cypselas and florets lacking the above combination of characters
Pappus present, at least half as long as cypsela body
Pappus absent or very small
Pappus of 5–40 scabrid bristles not expanded at base; cypselas 1–2.5 mm long
Pappus of 2–4 retrorsely barbed awns or 3–8 bristles expanded at base; cypselas 2.8–12 mm long
Pappus shorter than cypsela body, of 2–4 stiff, barbed awns; leaves usually lobed or compound, 6 cm long or more
Pappus longer than cypsela body, of 3–8 c. lanceolate scales, tapering to bristle-like tips; leaves simple, more or less conduplicate, under 2 cm long
[link through]
All florets bisexual, similar in appearance
Outer florets female with only style present, filiform or ligulate, sometimes ligule very short, inner florets bisexual or functionaly male
Cypselas flat with involute herbaceous wings with large incurved appendages at the apex; small annuals of north-west
Cypselas obovoid to obloid, lacking wings or appendages; annuals or perennials
[link through]
Capitula sessile, axillary; involucral bracts scarious, all erect or incurved, non-glandular; receptacle without scales; leaves under 1 cm long; rare north-western herb to c. 10 cm high

Capitula pedunculate, in terminal cymes; involucral bracts herbaceous, the outer ones spreading, inner ones erect, usually glandular; receptacle with scales; leaves mostly longer than 2 cm; erect to spreading herbs mostly more than 30 cm high
[link through]
Tall shrubs or trees of montane forests, with leaves to c. 25 cm long, white-woolly beneath
Herbs, subshrubs (sometimes scandent) or twiners
[link through]
Marginal florets sterile; erect purplish perennial of far east and north-east
Marginal florets fertile; leaves sometimes purplish beneath but plant not overall purplish
[link through]
Cypselas narrow-cylindric with a long straight or curved beak; outer florets strongly decurved in upper part and overhanging involucre
Cypselas and florets lacking the above combination of characters
Plants climbing, twining or trailing; leaves ivy-like, thin-textured; stipules present, reniform
Plants erect or decumbent, or if ever scandent then leaves thick-textured; stipules absent
[link through]
Common involucre surrounding the compound head of numerous scarious, opaque white or yellow bracts
Common involucre of few green leaves, scales or absent
Pappus of a single bristle; leaves narrow-linear, grass-like, glabrous or cobwebbed; compound heads sessile; plants under 10 cm high
Pappus of 9–15 bristles; leaves linear to lanceolate, glandular-pubescent; com- pound heads pedunculate; plants 10–50 cm high
[link through]
[link through]
Inflorescence sessile at ground-level, usually in a rosette of leaves; plants appar- ently stemless or stems prostrate
